destinations such as Spain, France, Italy and Germany.A full list of countries which the UK Government regards as posing aldquoreduced risk of Covid- will be published later today, and could feature as many as  nations.However, there is still a chance that travellers from the UK will have to self-isolate on arrival into some of the other states.The blanket guide against all but essential travel will also be changed tomorrow.What is an air bridge An air bridge, also known as a travel corridor, will allow tourists to travel between two countries without the need to quarantine.The agreements between countries, particularly those with low cases ofcoronavirus, allow two-way travel without restrictions.Do air bridges apply to Scotland The First Minister has criticised the UK Government for failing to consult the devolved administration before announcing the proposed changes.The Scottish Government says a four-nations agreement hasnot yet been reached.A spokesman said the UK Government is lting quarantine restrictions for countries ldquowhich present dfering levels of risk.ldquoIt is disappointing that the UK Government have chosen to make an announcement on the countries they intend to exempt before a four nations agreement has been reached, he said.ldquoWe would still like to reach a four nations approachpossible, but that is dficult when the UK Government change proposals and give us last-minute sight of them.While border controls remains a reserved matter, the issue of health is devolved ndash therefore allowing the Scottish Government to retain control over quarantine measures in this country.This means, as it stands, the current restrictions remain in place in Scotland for now.Could this change Speaking on Monday, the First Minister said she wanted to ldquotake a bit of time to consider the public health impact of removing the -day quarantine.She added she wanted to look at the evidence underpinning the decision south of the border and would feed back as soon as possible.What are the quarantine rules in Scotland The following measures were put in place from June :Residents and visitors arriving from abroad must self-isolate for  daysAll travellers must complete an online passenger locator form supplying contact details, travel details and the address of where they will self-isolateBorder Force will carry out spot checks at the border and can impose a fine of pound on those who refuse to comply.Arrangements will be made for those arriving into Scotland to be contacted during self-isolation to receive public health advice and informationThose who fail to self-isolate can be fined pound.Persistent offenders can be reported to the procurator fiscal for potential prosecution and a maximum pound, fine.

title: borders-rugby-pitch-become-beer-garden-plans
story: BORDERS revellers have snapped up every ticket for a ldquobeer garden event at Hawick rugby clubrsquos ground.The club plans to host drinkers on the Mansfield Park pitch at a series of events, starting on July .Talks with Scottish Borders Counciland the police are continuing today .A joint statement from the club and SBC reads: ldquoBoth the club and the council are hopeful that the planned event on Saturday, July , which has already been fully booked, will be able to take place, subject to all public health matters being resolved and the necessary licence being approved.Beer gardens in Scotland are allowed to open from Mondayas lockdown restrictions continue to be eased.This is the full statement issued on Thursday, July "Hawick Rugby Football Club and Scottish Borders Council would like to confirm that they continue to work together with a view to the club holding lsquobeer gardenrsquo events on the pitch."The club requires an occasional licence for these events to take place and has submitted an application today to Scottish Borders Council."A Safety Advisory Group meeting involving the club, Council and other relevant partners, including Police Scotland, will take place tomorrow to enable detailed discussions to take place on all necessary matters, including public health."In light of this, the club is reviewing its plans for events currently scheduled for the early part of next week."Both the club and the Council are hopeful that the planned event on Saturday  July, which has already been fully booked, will be able to take place, subject to all public health matters being resolved and the necessary licence being approved."

title: borders-book-festival-2020-line-up-revealed-july-talks
story: AN online version of the Borders Book Festival begins this month.Festival co-director Paula Ogilvie says ldquothe skyrsquos the limit for the series of talks, which kick off on July  and run every Sunday for  weeks.Stalwarts, including Rory Bremner and James Naughtie, will be back to entertain fans in the pre-recorded sessions.But they will also be joined by new names including YouTube chef Suzanne Mulholland ndash aka The Batch Lady ndash and childrenrsquos author Chris Lloyd.After each talk plays out live, authors will be available to answer questions at the end.The series has been organised because of the cancellation of the physical festival, which had been due to be held in June at Harmony House, Melrose.ldquoWe thought it was quite an important thing to do, said Mrs Ogilvie, on the idea of a virtual version.ldquoItrsquos not a perfect experience and we canrsquot replicate the real event, but at least the author is still there and still interacting with the audience.While audiences wonrsquot be sitting ldquoshoulder to shoulder and seeing the whites of the authorsrsquo eyes, it does mean more people will be able to join the festival, albeit virtually.Mrs Ogilvie said: ldquoWersquove got festival goers who now live in far flung places."We had a bit of response with people saying, lsquoI live in Canada now, I was really missing the festival but I can be part of it ndash I can watch it.rsquo So therersquos a good up side to it.The festival will also be able to talk to authors on the other side of the world.ldquoFor the August programme, wersquove got some names that are not based in the UK, said Mrs Ogilvie.ldquoThis allows us to have authors and thinkers who ordinarily wersquod have a bit of a challenge to get to the UK, never mind the Scottish Borders.But launch day will see one guest who is always happy toto the Borders ndash festival favourite Rory Bremner, in conversation with festival founder Alistair Moffat.ldquoRory Bremner is a real stalwart of the festival, said Mrs Ogilvie.ldquoHersquos been with us since , he appears every year and has also helped us to shape the programme.ldquoHersquoll do what Rory does ndash therersquoll be impersonations, and a lot of chat about the last  or so years that hersquos been involved in the festival and the highlights from that, so thatrsquoll be fun.Also appearing on July , in the pm slot, is internet sensation Suzanne Mulholland, aka The Batch Lady.The Batch Lady, whose book of the same name is out now, has garnered , followers on her YouTube, Instagram and Facebook channels. She has also appeared in Hellomagazine, the Daily Mailand The Sun.ldquoShersquos quite a phenomenon, said Mrs Ogilvie. ldquoShersquos already super popular but is gathering more momentum and I love the fact shersquos based in the Scottish Borders.,params: .pushldquoFor her event with us shersquoll talk about her book, but also do a -minute demonstration with a number of dferent recipes from the book.Other highlights of the July programme include journalist and broadcaster Kirsty Wark in conversation with former Vogueeditor Alexandra Shulman, and an evening with award-winning crime writers Mark Billingham and Chris Brookmyre.Moving the -year-old book festival online might have been a ldquosteep learning curve, according to Mrs Ogilvie, but it has also been essential to keep the event alive, and books and authors in the limelight.ldquoIt just means we can start to shine even more of a light on the Scottish Borders and our authors and what the festival does, said Mrs Ogilvie. ldquoThe skyrsquos the limit.Borders Book Festivals July programmeJuly am: Make Your Own Rockpool Book with Jill Calderpm: The Batch Ladypm: Rory Bremner in conversation with Alistair MoffatJuly am: Joseph Coelho  Fiona Lumbers: Luna Loves Artpm: Alexandra Shulman in conversation with Kirsty Warkpm: James NaughtieJuly am: Humanimal ndash Incredible Ways Animals are Just Like Us! with Chris Lloydpm: Paul Murton in conversation with Alistair Moffatpm: Mark Billingham in conversation with Chris BrookmyreAuthor names for August and September will be released at a later date.For more information, go to the Borders Book Festival website.

title: face-masks-buy-face-coverings-independent-stores-scotland
story: Face coverings are to become mandatory in Scotlands shops from July , First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced.The new rule comes just two weeks after passengers on public transport were told they must cover their faces when travelling.Some Scots across the country have already been practising the habit of wearing face masks when out in public, but as covering up becomes a legal requirement, many of us are now in the market for a quality face mask.Of course, major fashion brands such as ASOS, Boohoo and River Island were quick to get in on the action and are selling masks online.Butindependent and Scottish-made masks are more your style, here is our rundown of where in Scotland is selling the worldrsquos latest hot commodity.BroraWith Scottish cashmere at its heart, luxury clothing brand Brora began producing face masks for both adults and children from the surplus material at one of their Portuguese factories making PPE.Edinburgh store manager Sophie Hopkinson said: ldquoWe really wanted to come up with a great idea to give back, so pound from every mask will go to NHS charities and other small charities.ldquoThey are really nice to wear since theyrsquore a natural fibre, and ever since we opened theyrsquove been incredibly popular."Breathe EasyWhen the pandemic hit, engineer and entrepreneur Gavin McAdam got to work creating masks.His Edinburgh-based start-up Breathe Easy began by asking only for donations to try and help the third-party care sector and vulnerable groups get access to quality medical-grade face masks.And when someone got in touch askingMr McAdam could create a face mask for their deaf son, the company set about creating and trialling a cotton face mask with a transparent plastic face .Now Breathe Easy continues to issue free face masks to a iety of charities around Scotland, but also sells both full cotton masks and those with transparent  for deaf and hard of hearing communities on their website.Owner Gavin McAdam said: ldquoWersquore growing all the time and employing more people to keep up with demand.ldquoWersquore also working in partnership with the National Manufacturing Institute and Glasgow University in the development of a novel material that has natural microbial properties, engineered to capture the exact particle size of the Covid- virus."We will be trialling the first of these masks in two or three weeks."Slanj KiltsSlanj Kilts recently came into the limelight when Nicola Sturgeon was seen wearing one of their latest wares.The First Minister was spotted modelling the homeless tartan design, which sees % of all its sales donated to Shelter.General Manager Ross Lyall said: ldquoWe started making face masks in February in anticipation of lockdown. Sales were trickling through, but then of course Nicola wore our mask, and it went mental.ldquoThe traditional kilt business is dependent on the wedding industry, so we were very worried about the way things are at the moment and asking ourselves where the money is going to come fromthere are no weddings.ldquoSuddenly we had thousands of orders going through, so we are currently trying to recruit as many sowers as possible to keep up with demand.Mischke LingerieAs an Aberdeen-based brand known for its lingerie, this company is now also producing cloth masks in a iety of dferent colours and prints, with a pocket for a filter, for only pound..Designer Hazel Lethaby, founder of Mischke Lingerie said:"We have a passion for making small and beautul things and firmly believe that the Devil is in the detail."I started making masks as I saw a need to use my skills to produce something for the general public so that there was no need for people to buy up supplies of medical grade equipment."The masks I make are not designed as PPE but can be worn to comply with the guidelines in stores and on public transport."I am using mainly % cotton gingham as it has a stylish and playful look and its easy to wash, making the masks more sustainable. The design is also zero waste, there are no offcuts!"Mirka Bridal CoutureOwner of this Kirkcaldybridal store Mirka Jankowska has been hard at workcollaboratingwith Laila Letteringto produce limited edition face masks during lockdown.,params: .pushFor each face mask purchase Mirka Bridal Couture are donatinga face mask to the Childrenrsquos Oncology Ward in Edinburgh who are in need of reusable face masks for their young patients and their families.Julie Macintyre Handmade Bags Julie Macintyre, from Dalkeithnear Edinburgh,has pressed pause on making bags to create beautul Harris Tweed face masks.After trialling several designsshe found that the above product, with % cotton lining, was most comfortable to wear.Handmade by DotThis independent store has added face masks to its list of handmade items, which already includes bottle light lamps, hand-knitted items, handmade cards, and jewellery.The face masks come in a wide range of colours and patterns, are washable and double lined with a filter pocket.

title: tescos-major-changes-shopping-online
story: Tesco has confirmed a big change for people who regularly shop online and use their home delivery service.The retailer saysa feature that was previously suspended - due to coronavirus - has now ed.What is the change for online shoppers Tescos Delivery Saver plan - which stopped back in April - resumed on Wednesday, July .The supermarket giant says themove will make it easier for their most loyal customers to easily picka delivery slot.In an email to shoppers, Tesco said: "As you know, we suspended Delivery Saver payments in April, which allowed us to support , vulnerable customers with .million orders."We couldnt have done this without your patience and understanding."Wersquore now planning to restart Delivery Saver plans from  July."What  has changed Tesco has also updated themaximum item restriction for deliveries.When lockdown began in March, orders were limited to a maximum item number of .Now, the limit has been increased to amaximum of  items.What is theTesco Delivery Saver plan Delivery Saver is Tescos subscription-based delivery service, which is designed to help shoppers reduce the cost of home deliveries for their grocery orders.The plans come with a iety of benefits, according to Tesco.These include:Free delivery onshopping across all of Tescos online departments.If shoppers spend more on a plan than they would have done on deliveries, the retailer will email them an eCouponwith the dference -within  days of their plan ending.Customers will also earn points on every Delivery Saver payment, as well as collecting points on their shopping.Online shoppers will also be able to getearly access for delivery slots at Christmas and Easter.

title: scottish-open-take-place-renaissance-club-october
story: The impact of the coronavirus saw the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open postponed last month.However, the European Tour has now confirmed that the tournament, which will be played at The Renaissance Club, near Archerfield, will take place from October -.Keith Pelley, European Tour Chief Executive, said: ldquoSince the suspension of our  season in early March, we have taken a measured approach in reassessing our schedule, informed every step of the way by our medical advisers and government guidance.ldquoWe have consistently said that safety is our absolute priority and that is why today we are announcing our resumption in two monthsrsquo time supported by a comprehensive health strategy which has been led by our medical team.ldquoWithout question we have had to think dferently about the remainder of our  season which is reflected in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoAs golfrsquos global Tour, ersity is ordinarily one of our biggest strengths, but in this instance it has become one of our biggest challenges.ldquoInitially, therefore, based on the expert guidance we received, playing in clusters, in one territory, is the best option in terms of testing, travel and accommodation.It is the second year in a row that the competition has been played at the East Lothian course.Last yearrsquos event was won by Bernd Wiesberger after a play-off with Benjamin Hebert.Among those hoping to line up at the tournament is North Berwicks Grant Forrest.The -year-old, who finished tied for rd at least years event, said: "It is great it is going ahead."Obviously, so much uncertainty in the last few months and the guys on the European Tour have been working really hard to put something together for us."I am glad they have got it on the schedule and I hope the weather is alright in October ndash who knows what it could be like "There was a point where I thought it would almost be a year off, which would have been a real shame."They have done really well to give us so many events already and with the hope they could add a few more."Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to hear the event had been rescheduled.He said: ldquoI very much look forward to welcoming world class golfers back to East Lothian for this fantastic tournament."We will of course work closely with the European Tour and in accordance with guidance on the detail of how the tournament can be run safely."It is an encouraging development and signals that Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast will be back open for business this year albeit with some restrictions still in place.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, was similarly pleased to see the event rescheduled but stressed it remained to be seen how the tournament would look in terms of a crowd.He said: "I think it is great news not only for Scottish golf itself but for tourism in general."Hopefully, by then, we will be able to have crowds as well but I am really not sure what the rules on that are going to be yet ndash whether it is crowds or played behind closed doors, it would be a bit oddit was behind closed doors."In general, we will have to wait and see what the rules are about crowds."That is what produces the benefit in the short-term to the local economy."Mr Findlay highlighted that the tourism sector had taken "a huge hit" during the coronavirus crisis and many businesses would have to survive until next year before tourism started to resume in the traditional way.Currently, the Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is pencilled in for August - at the same venue.Last yearrsquos event was won by Mi Jung Hur.

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: high-school-students-snap-photography-contest-top-prizes
story: Carla Mulholland and Declan Longmuir were celebrating some picture perfect images after being crowned winners in the Scottish Civic Trustrsquos My Place Photography competition.The national competition encourages budding photographers, aged between four and , to explore the buildings, architecture and archaeology in the places they live, and experiment with using photography as a means of investigation and creative expression.The competition has free entry, and is open to schools, youth groups, clubs and home-educated young people.The theme for submissions in  was water, in celebration of Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters.Carla, , who is in S at the Prestonpans high school, was the overall winner in the secondary school category for her photograph lsquoAutumn Leavesrsquo.Saskia Hanmer, from Dunbar Grammar School, was highly commended for her picture, titled lsquoTime Delaysrsquo.Meanwhile, S pupil Declan Longmuir was also celebrating.The -year-old won the Young Personsrsquo Choice Award for his photograph lsquoChristmas at Port Seton Harbourrsquo.A spokesman for the school said: ldquoThis is a real achievement for PL, as our photography course is a short course, recently introduced to the curriculum.ldquoCongratulations to both pupils!Each year, winners of the My Place Photography Competition are honoured at a reception and their entries are displayed in a public exhibition.The  reception and exhibition launch, which was planned for April  at Glasgow Doors Open Days festival hub The Lighthouse, has been rescheduled for September this year.Fiona Hyslop MSP, cabinet secretary for economy, fair work and culture, said: ldquoI want to congratulate all of this yearrsquos entrants for the exceptional standard of photography that has again been produced by Scotlandrsquos schoolchildren for the My Place Photography Awards, and the many inventive ways in which they have captured their local built environments.ldquoThe awards are a terric way to stimulate interest and to nurture a concern for our surroundings from an early age, and itrsquos great that we can still enjoy seeing the world through the eyes of our young people, by way of the online gallery this year.

title: letter-week-tribute-east-lothians-retiring-msp
story: Iain exemplies the very best in public service.His motivation and his hard work have always been about improving the lives of others.During his career at Holyrood, his contribution in health and social care, and in education, have helped improve the quality of le, and le chances, of many.I have had the privilege of seeing that work first hand, sharing an office with Iain in Tranent for five years.Iainrsquos values extend beyond his politics to the way he lives his le, and the way he responds to people.He is a great person to have as a colleague and friend.As well as being generous with his experience and advice, we shared many laughs. In more dficult times, he was equally generous with his support and understanding and I will always be grateful to him for that.For Iain, putting East Lothian first has been so much more than a line in a leaflet.He loves our county and has been an enduring supporter of local communities, organisations and businesses.I hope this doesnrsquot read like an obituary, in a political or any other sense.I have no doubt that he will work hard for us in the lead up to the Scottish Parliament in May , and beyond that he will continue to make valuable contributions to political discourse in Scotland, and to make a dference here in East Lothian.Through your letters page I want to thank Iain for his years of public service in East Lothian, and on a personal note to thank him for his constant friendship.We are all very fortunate to have such a man in our lives.Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell

title: shielding-dad-runs-half-marathon-back-garden
story: Stephen Ferguson, , who has asthma, undertook the challenge as he is lsquoshieldingrsquo during the Covid- lockdown after receiving advice from the NHS.He is no stranger to half marathons, having completed three in the past ndash Glentress Trail, Edinburgh and Stirling.This time round, he took his treadmill outside at his home and finished his lsquogardenrsquo half marathon ndash . miles ndash in one hour,  minutes and  seconds.His efforts have so far raised around pound for First Step, which supports families with young children.Mr Ferguson, who works with the Royal Bank of Scotland in Haddington, lives on Musselburghrsquos Galt Crescent, near First Step in Galt Avenue, and was inspired to take on the fundraising challenge as his three-year-old son Cormac enjoys attending its nursery.His we Louise also attended baby classes there with Cormac.Originally from Omagh, in Northern Ireland, Mr Ferguson has lived in Scotland since October , and married Louise last October.He also has a stepdaughter, Aaliyah, .He was helped with his training by Junior Burton of JB Combat Bootcamp, Wallyford, who was there to cheer on Mr Ferguson from a safe distance.Mr Ferguson said: ldquoThe run was really good. title: alasdair-northrops-debut-book-shares-tales-tourist-guides
story: Alasdair Northrop spent the past  months researching and writing Guiding Lights: A History of the Scottish Tourist Guides Association -.It tells the story of the Scottish Tourist Guides Association, which celebrated its th anniversary last year.Alasdair qualied as a blue badge tourist guide in  and quit his job as a journalist to go full-time in .He later joined the board of the Scottish Tourist Guides Associationand became chair of its marketing committee.When he learned that STGA would be celebrating its diamond anniversary last year, he suggested writing a book about its history.He said: ldquoI started researching its history in autumn , going through old committee papers and newsletters and interviewing some of the older guides.ldquoI then did a talk about its history at our th anniversary AGM in March last year but I had still not finished the book.ldquoOnce the tourist season was under way I could not do any more work on it until November last year.ldquoThe coronavirus crisis resulted in the cancellation of all my work this year and I have used some of the time to finish off this book.ldquoIt has been a fascinating project and I discovered there was a lot to write about.He added: ldquoOne of the purposes of the STGA was to create lsquoprofessionalrsquo guides who not only learned about Mary Queen of Scots but who also knew how to make sure a large group of tourists didnrsquot get run down when crossing a busy road!ldquoNot surprisingly,you are writing a book about tourist guides there are some really interesting tales to tell.ldquoAmong them is the story about how a guide took Prince Edward and his friends on an incognito tour of Edinburgh Castle, where the royal family member queued with everyone  to see the Crown jewels.Today, STGA has more than  active members, a number of whom live in East LothianAlasdair said: ldquoAs I am a member of the board I am not allowed to make any money from the book so all the proceeds are going to the association, which is very useful at this particular time.ldquoI hope the book will be of interest to anyone involved in the history of Scottish tourism and there are some very amusing stories in it for the general reader.Alasdair said he was looking forward to the reopening of Scottish tourism next month.He added: ldquoI am an optimist by nature, and you can be sure we will see tourist guides .ldquoNew skills and new ways of working will be required and I am confident members of the Scottish Tourist Guides Association will meet that challenge.The book is available as an ebook on Amazon, and Alasdair hopes to see it in print one day.

title: mediator-services-solve-lockdown-conflict
story: Robin Burley, an Inveresk resident, and Malcolm Currie, from Musselburgh, are supporting a new mediation service launched across Scotland with help from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Wellbeing Fund.Conflicts can include a personal relationship that is under duress as a result of self-isolation or a dispute with an employer about ing to work during the Covid- outbreak.Anyone is eligible for the service : they live in Scotland the conflict is connected to social distancing or self-isolation it is not part of a pre-existing dispute, for example, orce proceedings or formal contact arrangements and all of the people in the conflict agree to participate in mediation.Provided by a group of professional volunteer mediators, the service is free to iniduals and organisations with up to five employees.Organisations with more than five employees will be charged pound for up to one dayrsquos mediation. The service can be accessed through the Scottish Mediation website or by emailing admin@scottishmediation.org.uk.Mr Currie founded Strathesk Resolutions after more than a decade working as a trades union negotiator.Engaging with employers in the private, public and third sectors, he developed his expertise in collective bargaining, dispute resolution and tackling complex inidual cases.These skills were built on a foundation of over  years advising and influencing countryside managers in relation to land management and pulling together funding packages from wide-ranging sources for joint projects.He has helped organisations as erse as aircraft engineering, academic research institutes, heritage bodies and charitable trusts to establish effective workforce consultation mechanisms, and to operate them to the greatest effect for company performance.Mr Currie said: ldquoAs with any disagreement or dispute,we arenrsquot able to have a conversation about it andit remains unresolved, the frustration that can create can end up being greater than the original reason why there was a disagreement.ldquoThat can often have impacts on mental health and wellbeing so it is goodpeople are able to speak about whatrsquos happening.Mr Burley has been mediating for  years, having carried out more than  mediations which draw on his mediation training and  years of work and le experience in housing, community care and organisational governance.His mediation practice has developed with its focus on civil justice mediation, employment, workplace, commercial, construction, property, urban, rural, agricultural and complaints.He initially trained with Core Solutions in  and, after taking a degree course in mediation and conflict resolution at Strathclyde University, he gained a masterrsquos degree with distinction in .He stood down from six years as chairman of Scottish Mediation in .Prior to working as a mediator and coach, he spent  years in housing and care services and urban development.He was chief executive of the Edin Group, a past chair of Blackwood, ELCAP and the Built Environment Forum Scotland .He has also held non-executive director positions with NHS Lothian, Queen Margaret University and the Scottish Federation of Housing Associations.Mr Burley commented: ldquoMediators are able to help create the space for that conversation in a way which allows the parties to use creative ways of resolving disagreements and in some instances to repair relationships, too.ldquoIn terms of what might be a suitable dispute for mediation, we will be able to speak to you about your dispute and advise on each instance.ldquoAs a general guide, the sorts of disputes include those around family matters, including care of older relatives, flatmates housemates, landlord tenant, co-operative or social housing, workplace concerns related to working from home or shared workspaces and those involving neighbours.ldquoIt is possible that some issues may have existed before and were being managed successfully but the additional pressures have pushed them into conflict.Graham Boyack, director of Scottish Mediation, added: ldquoThis is a challenging time for everyone and the isolation and stress of living in close quarters can cause, or increase, conflict for families, friends, and roommates, and can create challenges for work teams, charities and businesses.

title: preston-athletic-footballers-getting-bikes-good-causes
story: Members of Prestonpans-based Preston Athleticrsquos squad are getting on their bikes for a special fundraiser, which will see them visit the homes of  football teams in East Lothian, Edinburgh and Midlothian.Money raised will be split between the East of Scotland side and the NHS, as a thank you for the hard work of its staff.The cycle, had been due to take place last Saturday but was postponed to a still-to-be-confirmed new date, was the idea of team-mates Kai Austin and Nathan Stokes.Twenty-one-year-old Kai, who plays right back for the side, said: ldquoA lot of clubs have been making signings and we knew Preston were struggling even to just keep going.ldquoI have seen where someone has cycled or driven to the  league grounds [in the Scottish Premiership to League Two].ldquoWe thought maybe it would be a cool idea to do something like that at our level.ldquoWe came up with a challenge to entice people to want to donate and will us on.ldquoWe came up with visiting  grounds for  teams for the   season.The teammates plan to start at New Countess Park, home of Dunbar United.From there, it is on to Millfield , Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The cyclists will then head into Midlothian and tick off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Park , Ferguson Parkand Penicuik Park .Then it is into the Capital for stops at Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosure , Christie Gillies Park , Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand finally Peffermill .Finally, the weary cyclists willto East Lothian and tick off Olivebankbefore reaching the finish line and familiar surroundings of The Pennypit .In total, the cycle, which is about  kilometres , is expected to take upwards of seven hours, with the players stopping for a photograph at each ground.The fundraiser is also the latest step on the road to recovery for midfielder Nathan.The -year-old missed the entire   season after a horror ankle injury in pre-season, which saw ligaments ripped off the bone.Now, he is keen to get back to fitness ahead of the new campaign kicking off.He said: ldquoI have still been going to watch matches and getting the changing room banter.ldquoWe are all in a group chat and a lot of the boys have been working on their fitness throughout lockdown.ldquoThey have been out running or cycling and a lot of the boys are keen to get back to it and we are all missing it, especially myself.ldquoI am hoping to be back for next season.ldquoIt has been a long hard battle to get back fit after surgery.ldquoIt has been three months since surgery and the doctor and physio said it would be three to six months before I am back playing.Nathan, who previously played for Musselburgh Windsor and Ormiston, has played at most of the grounds but will tick off visiting Haddington, Newtongrange Star, Arniston Rangers and Civil Service Strollers during the cycle.He was looking forward to the fundraiser and was pleased with the reaction from members of the public, with more than pound already donated.He said: ldquoMy mum is a carer, Irsquove got family and friends who work in the NHS, so it is a no brainer to be honest.ldquoMyself and Kai said we should half the money with the NHS. The work they are doing just now is remarkable.To support the club, go to www.justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: community-resilience-happening-cockenzie-port-seton-dirleton-longniddry-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience team in Cockenzie and Port Seton has started to plan for how its work can continue once schoolsin August.The effort is being led by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council.Bryan Hickman, group chairman, said: ldquoWe are working on what we will do when the schools go back. We will continue as best we can till then.ldquoWe are making plans.ldquoWhen the schools do go back, at the moment the plan is that they wonrsquot all go back at once so we might need to help families and kids while they are not at school.The resilience team is also discussing how its support efforts can continue during the easing of lockdown restrictions.The group received a third consignment of childrenrsquos craft packs from Walk With Scott Foundation, which are now being delivered throughout the community.The packs include items such as crayons, bee and butterfly colouring sheets and a butterfly feeding kit.Bryan extended his thanks to those at the Walk With Scott Foundation for their generous donation.Work on the sports hall extension at the Port Seton Centre has resumed after it was paused due to the coronavirus.Bryan told the Courier that the contractor was back on site and had resumed work on the pound million extension.Work initially started in October last year, with the hope it would be completed next month.Contact detailsThose in isolation, who are housebound or require assistance can still contact the team on  .Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonVOLUNTEERS have vowed to continue offering support to people throughout Dirleton despite lockdown restrictions being eased.The Dirleton Area Resilience Teamis continuing its ongoing support for the local community.With the easing of pandemic restrictions and the lockdown, it has continued to be at the forefront of planning for, and critical analysis of, the situation.DARTrsquos primary services remain the same, with shopping and prescription requests being completed, dog walking being carried out and volunteers on hand to provide support when needed.David Tait, DART lead co-ordinator, said: ldquoAlthough the village and wider area seem to be gradually ing to normal, we are in no way complacent in our approach to the support we give.ldquoWe continue to monitor the situation on a day by day basis and we have contingency plans in place, ready for roll out in any eventuality ndash such as a possible second spike of the virus or to provide support to families who may be at risk when the furlough scheme is wound down and with the possibility of job losses.ldquoWersquore monitoring the position and we aim to keep our community up to date on whatrsquos happening as soon as we know about it.Meanwhile, the community essentials larder remains a vital asset within the village, with an increase in regular visits.The larder had been set to move to more permanent premises but this has been delayed.Jack Findlay, landlord of the Castle Inn in the village, has allowed DART to extend its time at the premises with the larder.David added: ldquoWithout Jackrsquos generosity we would have lost this vital asset, one on which our community continues to depend.ldquoWe are forever grateful to Jack and his family for the support they are giving to the DART team.ldquoThere arenrsquot enough words out there to thank them for their kindness.Contact detailsFor continued and up to date information on DARTrsquos activities, go to www.dirletonresilience.orgLongniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryTHE resilience effort in Longniddry is still available for people who need to use it and the local dental practice has introduced new rules as part of its reopening during phase two of the easing of lockdown restrictions.Anyone who needs to contact the practice is asked to call first, as the door will be locked.People will be asked screening questions before appointments, which they are encouraged to attend alone.There will be hand sanitiser at reception and the toilet will remain closed.Appointments will be spaced out to allow for social distancing.People are being encouraged to pay using contactless methods and staff will be wearing additional PPE.Meanwhile, despite not receiving a lot of requests for help, the resilience effort is still available for those who need it.Longniddry residents can also benefit from the food pantry in Port Seton Centre.The pantry is open pm to pm, Monday to Friday.Delivery can be arranged by calling  .There is also a food pantry at the Pennypit Centre in Prestonpans, from am to pm.Contact detailsIf anyone needs support or assistance of any kind, they are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS community resilience effort is now looking at winding down some of its volunteer activities as members of its teamto work and demand for support reduces as people who have been shielding are allowed to got out under an easing of restrictions.Brian Weddell, chairperson of Prestonpans Community Council, said thoughts were turning to winding down resilience work after more than three months of ldquotremendous effort.But he stressed that the hardship fund set up by the community council to help those finding it dficult in lockdown remainsed and anyone who needed support could still call the resilience team for help.He said: ldquoOur thoughts are turning to winding down our resilience efforts. ldquoThere has been a tremendous amount of work put in by our volunteers in Prestonpans since the start of lockdown on March  and we cannot thank them enough for their support.ldquoAt the start of this, our volunteers delivered leaflets to every household in the Pans and during the past three months have delivered meals and shopping, collected food donated from supermarkets, collected prescriptions for people self-isolating and shielding and last, but not least, walked the dogs for people unable to get out.ldquoThe relaxation of the rules by the Scottish Government allows our volunteers to start to wind down but their magnicent efforts on behalf of their local community should not be forgotten.ldquoWithout their selfless efforts the past three months would have been a lot tougher for many people living in Prestonpans.Brian added: ldquoWhilst the work of our resilience volunteers is quietening down, le at the Pennypit Pantry carries on, with food parcels being delivered daily to the elderly, and many families now collecting food from the Pagoda in North Grange Avenue.ldquoLast week, the Pantry provided  meals to the elderly and families in Prestonpans, which included almost  deliveries each day.Anyone in Prestonpans who needs support with meals or essential groceries can call the Pennypit Pantry on   or email lornabellany@gmailAs well as the Pennypit Pantry, Jane Russellrsquos Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinners are still being provided, and last weekend they delivered  dinners.Sunday dinners can be ordered via East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinners via its Facebook page or by calling  .Contact detailsAnyone who needs help can contact the team by calling their hotline telephone number on   or by emailing them at prestonpansresilience@gmail

story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Gford. village who may be struggling to afford household and food essentials, and is also providing support to older residents who are less confident about venturing out or able to visit larger supermarkets.Posters are on display in the village, and leaflets are being distributed to every household, with information about the larder, and Yester Primary School has been asked to ensure families who may struggle financially during the school summer holiday are aware of the services available.A spokesperson for Gford Community Council said tit was grateful to everyone who had donated current situation.ldquoShould the network be lsquostood downrsquo, we are committed to continuing with services such as Soup and a Smile and the Gford Larder as part of Gford Community Councilrsquos activities.ldquoFinally, we are very grateful to Haddington and Lammermuir Area Partnership for funding towards our food projects, which help us to continue with confidence.Contact detailsAnyone who on   or anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonA PROJECT designed to keep people entertained during the coronavirus pandemic has been hailed a success.Haddingtonrsquos to make this, not painless, but slightly better for the town and make everybodyrsquos le a lot easier.ldquoIt is a testament to every group in the town.Contact detailsAnyone needing assistance can still visit www.haddingtoncc.org.uk or call   between am and pm.East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsHumbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonCOMMUNITY resilience efforts are continuing in Bolton.Volunteers continue to pick up shopping and prescriptions for people in need in the village.Shena Jamieson, who is the single point of contactin Bolton, said it was ldquobusiness as usual and no new people had got in touch recently.Contact detailsFor those needing assistance, people in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by emailing shenajamieson@aolEast Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahooIn West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmailIn Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMusselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghA FRESH appeal has been made for volunteers to help Resilient Musselburgh as the Covid- lockdown eases.Organisers are keen to ensure there are replacements for helpers whose circumstances might change in the next few months as restrictions are lted.Iain Clark, chairman of the Musselburgh Area Partnership, said: ldquoResilient Musselburgh cannot thank our pool of community volunteers enough for the support they have provided over the last three months.ldquoIt would be an understatement to say that we could not have responded to this crisis without them because, the reality is, we could not have!ldquoAs we plan ahead for the next few months and the summer holiday period, we are conscious that many peoplersquos circumstances may have changed and may continue to do so as we move through the phases of lockdown removal.ldquoTo ensure that we can sustain support through our network of community volunteers we would ask anyone who would like to volunteer to sign up by contacting us at resilientmusselburgh@gmail and this will help us to continue our efforts in the community.Iain said: ldquoResilient Musselburgh continues to provide an emergency support to our community with the provision of meals, food and activity as is necessary, and we are currently reviewing all the emergency support we are providing so we can establish a clear exit plan as we move through the phases, and ultimately phase down our emergency response as appropriate.He added: ldquoWe are extremely grateful to the local SNP group for their recent financial donation to Resilient Musselburgh.Contact detailsFor more information, contactresilientmusselburgh@gmail

title: six-new-things-can-today-scotlands-lockdown-eased
story: The First Minister last week confirmed an acceleration of easing restrictions across the country following a continued suppression of the virus.But Nicola Sturgeonhas since urged the public not to ldquosquander that progress as we move into more freedom.Here, we detail out the six changes taking place today:Shopping and outdoor marketsOne of the most anticipated announcements from lockdown, non-essential shopsare now officially allowed to reopen.The one restriction still in place, however, is these must be street-access retail. Non-essential stores within shopping centres malls must remain closed until Phase .Commenting on the re-opening this morning, the First Minister tweeted: ldquoIf you plan on visiting shops today, please do so responsibly.ldquoMaintain physical distancing, follow hygiene advice, wear a face covering and respect staff who may be asking you to shop dferently.ldquoWersquove made so much progress against the virus ndash letrsquos not squander it. #StaySafe.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.On Friday, First Minister @NicolaSturgeon set out guidance on how to #StaySafe when some shops reopen today following changes to #coronavirus measures.Find out more ## https:t.co DwqbXAFMk pic VVuUhPzZWorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .This does NOT include indoor workspaces that are due to open in Phase  ndash like non-essential offices and call-centres.Moving homeFrom today, all home moves are permitted, provided they can be carried out safely.This includes students moving home and other home moves resulting in two households merging.It also applies to custom and self-builders looking to acquire a plot or a property to renovate or to demolish.The Scottish Government has issued guidance around this ndash as well as encouraging people to take part in virtual property viewings as much as possible with further guidance around health and safety here.Outdoor sports courts and playgroundsFrom today, outdoor sports courts can reopen to the public.This includes courts for tennis, basketball, volleyball , Multi-Use Games Areasand netball.Participants must maintain strict physical distancing at all times when using outdoor sports courts. This does not include pitches used for contact sports.Playgrounds can also reopen.These were closed at the start of lockdown amid fears the virus could spread through the physical contact in these areas.Marriages and civil partnershipsMarriages and civil partnerships can resume from today.These have to have a minimal number of attendees and, despite the Scottish weather, be outdoors only.All the participants, including the couple and the witnesses, must come from no more than three households and will be possible up to amaximum of eight.The celebrant or registrar will not count as one of the households.Zoos and garden attractionsMust to the anticipation of those in Edinburgh, zoos and garden attractions can open from today.However the Scottish Government guidance says these are initially for local access only ndash meaning people broadly within five miles can attend.Increased hygiene measures are encouraged, with pre-booking tickets online also advised.

title: east-lothian-council-shop-local-campaign
story: East Lothian Council has launched a campaign for residents to lsquoStay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothianrsquo by using local shops and businesses.With many businesses hit hard by the Covid- pandemic, retailersacross the county re-opened this week and introduced social distancing measures to keep customers and staff safe.And the council is calling on people to back their local shops and services by using them while following safety advice.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos Provost and spokesperson for economic development and tourism, said: ldquoEast Lothianrsquos shops and local businesses have had to face particularly challenging circumstances over the last few months, but, as our high streets start to open up again, they are keen to welcome existing and new customersldquoIrsquom delighted to support the launch of East Lothian Councilrsquos new campaign ndash Stay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothian.ldquoItrsquos about sending out a message that East Lothian is getting back open for business ndash whatever products or services yoursquore looking for, yoursquore very likely to find them here in East Lothian.ldquoLocal businesses are essential for our economy. They bring growth and innovation, provide employment and support the local economies and communities. They also care about their community.ldquoBy continuing to stay safe and shop locally the people of East Lothian can help local businesses, so integral to the fabric and character of our community, to not only survive but thrive.The campaign comes as East Lothian councillor Craig Hoy, who is the Scottish Conservative candidate for the Holyrood  election, launched a locallsquoSupport Our High Streetsrsquo campaign.Mr Hoy has already called on the council to make it easier for local restaurants, cafes and bars to re-open by allowing them to use public space near their venues to provide al fresco services.He said: ldquoWith East Lothianrsquos shops re-opening, itrsquos vital that we Support Our High Streets, save jobs and help the local economy bounce back.ldquoWe can all do our bit by making sure we shop local and visit our fantastic range of cafes, restaurants and bars as they begin to re-open.

title: east-lothian-council-safe-space-funding
story: The local authority has been given pound.million of Scottish Government funding to allow it to transform its high streets and bring shoppers back.However, the plans have sparked concern among some residents, who questioned whether the council would use the money to introduce long-term changes proposed before lockdown which brought mixed reactions form the public.One person on social media accused them of using a ldquoback door to get what they want.While Haddington councillor Craig Hoy warned that improvements had to be made without creating unnecessary restrictionsHe said: ldquoIt is important that our high streets are capable of allowing pedestrians to be able to socially distance, giving people the confidence to get out and about.ldquoBut, at the same time, itrsquos important we donrsquot impose unnecessary restrictions or reduce parking provision in a way which is detrimental to trade.ldquoWe need to strike a careful balance here and ensure the interventions are proportionate.The local authority launched its bid for funds from the Spaces for People Fund last month with a public consultation online.It drew just under , responses, with  detailed comments about improvements for town centres and roads.Although the funding is for temporary measures, the online questionnaire asked those taking partthey would support changes ldquolong term.Many people who took part in the survey called for pavements to be widened and speed reductions on some streets, as well as improved cycle lanes and footpaths.The council initially said it was applying for pound, from the Spaces for People Fund but has revealed it received nearly four times the original amount.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute council leader and environment spokesperson, said: ldquoThe pound.m funding will enable East Lothian Council to introduce a number of temporary measures to our streets as further easing of lockdown restrictions are applied.ldquoMany local shops are re-opening for business and these temporary changes are focused on protecting public health by providing necessary space for continued observance of physical distancing whilst supporting businesses and their customers.ldquoWhilst planning these new temporary changes, we have taken into account the erse needs of local communities to ensure as much as possible that those with mobility or sight concerns will be as supported as able-bodied iniduals.ldquoThese measures will create space for everyone, whether on foot, bike, wheelchair or using prams and buggies, and will support the initial stages of local economic recovery.The council said detailed plans of the changes to be introduced were still being discussed and no maps or additional information were currently available.However, it said a staged approach would be taken, with measures to be introduced including temporary widening of some footways, mph speed limits, some segregated space for cycling and opportunities for businesses to use pavement space for customer queuing.Some parking spaces within town centres may be temporarily removed.

title: boxing-fan-floored-birthday-wish-world-champion-josh-taylor
story: Mckenzie Kearsley-Edmond celebrated turning  on June  and received a signed picture of Josh Taylor in action.However, it was a present he could not unwrap that really floored the youngster.Taylor, , took time out from his training regime to film a short video wishing Mckenzie, who hopes to follow in the boxerrsquos footsteps and join Lochend Amateur Boxing Club, a happy birthday.His dad Chris Kearsley, who lives in Dunbar, said: ldquoIrsquove never seen him so emotional in my le. He was just about in tears of happiness.The incredible gt came about through Chris, who is a self-employed joiner, getting in touch with Jenner Charlton.The Duns-based photographer has been a regular at Taylorrsquos fights and was able to not only arrange for a signed picture of the boxer in action against Ryan Martin but also line up the birthday message.Taylor, from Prestonpans but now living in Haddington, said: ldquoHi Mckenzie, hi wee man, happy birthday.ldquoHope you have a great day and Irsquoll see you at Lochend [Amateur Boxing Club] one day when it opens back up.ldquoWersquoll do a bit of training together.Mckenzie, who is going into P at Dunbar Primary School, has been clocking up the miles watching ldquohis hero.He has taken in fights in Glasgow and even met Taylor in unusual circumstances before the county fighter lted the IBF World Super Lightweight title against Ivan Baranchyk.His dad said: ldquoWe were staying at the Radisson RED in Glasgow and got into the lt on the seventh floor.ldquoThe lt stopped on the sixth floor and Shane and Barry McGuigan and Josh all got in and we got a picture with them.Mckenzie and his dad even travelled to London in October to see Taylor put his newly claimed world title up against Regis Prograis and his WBA World Super Lightweight championship.Chris said: ldquoIrsquove always been a boxing fan and kept up training for the last wee while.ldquoWe started following Josh and found out he was from Prestonpans.ldquoWe went to watch his fight with Viktor Postol in Glasgow, and Lynne Wilson [an ASN auxiliary at Dunbar Primary School] is Joshrsquos cousin.ldquoWe started going to Joshrsquos fights and Mckenzie became interested in boxing.ldquoHe joined the Bronx Boxing Gym in Tranent and was doing a bit of training there.ldquoWe went to all the World Boxing Super Series fights and went to the final in London against Regis Prograis.ldquoMckenzie was on cloud nine for a week afterwards it was a great atmosphere!

title: visitors-given-green-light-return-eskgreen
story: The facility ndash on Shorthope Street near the River Esk ndash closed in mid-March and escaped the deadly virus. Run by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership , the  residents, aged between  and , have been keeping ldquoin good heart during the lockdown.An ELHSCP spokesperson confirmed: ldquoNo one has contracted Covid- at Eskgreen.Now, in line with Scottish Governmentguidance, the residents are looking forward to meeting visitors in outdoor areas only on Wednesdays and Saturdays, -.am and -pm, and Sundays, -pm and -.pm.At the moment, visits are restricted to one lsquokey visitorrsquo and will be held in outdoor areas.Clair Anderson, manager, said: ldquoItrsquos been hard because obviously people are missing their families and friends, but we all know why it has to be this way and we decided to make the best we could of it.ELHSCP introduced very restricted visiting to its four care homes, including Eskgreen, in mid-March, swtly followed by no visiting from March .Clair said: ldquoWe had to act very quickly but I think residents and families understood why and were behind us.ldquoWe managed to get our hands on Kindles and iPads very quickly and helped residents to Skype and FaceTime family and friends. This has really helped to keep people in touch regularly and relieve familiesrsquo anxieties.ldquoWe have a brilliant team spirit in Eskgreen. Relatives and staff have pulled together throughout the outbreak and have concentrated on trying to get as much out of le as possible, even though we were all living through a very challenging time.ldquoWe have kept ourselves really busy and really positive. I think the key to it is trying to get as much fun out of le as you can. So, we have had skittles evenings, birthday parties, Easter celebrations and we pulled out all the stops for VE Day ndash we even had a piper playing in the grounds.ldquoWersquove also had wonderful support from community groups, who have sent gts for us ndash residents and staff! Itrsquos brilliant to have such tangible proof that everyone is thinking of us.ldquoWersquove focused on being active and creative ndash we sing, we dance, we even made a video ndash Somewhere Over the Rainbow ndash which went viral locally."You can see it at bit.ly CZizla and it features residents singing The Wizard of Oz classic and is guaranteed to bring a tear to the eye.ldquoItrsquos also about helping people feel good about themselves so wersquove done a lot of pampering sessions ndash we all have lovely hair and great nails.ldquoWersquove had great help from ELHSCPrsquos care home team too. Theyrsquore a nurse-led team that have been working in care homes across East Lothian for the last four years.ldquoIn addition to their routine work of looking after the clinical needs of residents, like medication and wound care, they also really stepped up to help us during Covid.ldquoThey made sure that all the care homes they work with were on top of the guidance, which was being updated all the time, had access to all the PPE they needed and knew how and when to use it.ldquoI think all care homes in East Lothian, ELHSCP and private, have been doing their very best to keep people cheerful and safe.ldquoAt Eskgreen, I would have to say that we have great support from families, a great staff team and, most of all, great residents. Thatrsquos the secret of our success.Irene Tait, chair of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, said: ldquoWe were delighted and heartened at the way the management and staff of Eskgreen have coped with the coronavirus.ldquoThrough their diligence and great care, they have kept the residents and staff safe from contracting the virus.ldquoWe are all aware of the huge debt of thanks we owe to everyone working in our health and care sector however, itrsquos especially nice to hear good news in our own town and we can be very proud of them.ldquoI would also like to thank everyone who has rallied round to help neighbours, family and strangers at this time ndash it all matters.

title: impressive-floral-display-thank-key-workers
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos Dunbar amenity service team planted the colourful display outside the townrsquos fashion school on Belhaven Road.The design was created by James Scott , assisted by Kenny Aitken, Jamie Smith and trainee Dan Sked.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the town and is the local authorityrsquos spokesman for the environment, told the Courier he was impressed by the work of those involved.He said: ldquoIt is certainly impressive.ldquoIt just shows you the quality of the workmanship we have within our grounds services department, not only in Dunbar but across East Lothian.ldquoThe budget they have to work with is very limited but they do a fantastic job.ldquoAll the plants are grown by our own staff and planted out across the communities across East Lothian.Mr Hampshire described the planting as ldquoa beautul display and an asset to the town.The display uses echeveria elegans for the writing and the main heart contains echeveria Duchess of Nuremberg, pyrethrum, sedum pachyclados, senecio serpens, lobelia and petunia.The surrounding hearts are a mixture of echeverias, sedum, senecio, saxrage, alyssum, petunia, begonia, lobelia and pyrethrum.

title: star-peppa-pig-delights-children-hub-message
story: Daddy Pig sent the children and staff at The Hub at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, Tranent,best wishes as he urged youngsters to ldquobe kind to people.The greeting, which was shared on Twitter, was recorded by actor Richard Ridings, who voices Daddy Pig in the popular cartoon series.In the -second-long message, he sent special greetings to all the children who attended The Hub and their teachers and staff.He told them: ldquoI know we are living in a very, very strange time at the moment but as long as we keep on smiling and keep being kind to people then I think wersquoll all be alright.The message was recorded after Mr Ridings, who played Bernard Green in the BBCrsquos Common As Muck and was also in Alan Ashburnrsquos drama Fat Friends, was approached by the parent of one of the children at the school.And it was shared on Twitter by the school, which admitted depute headteacher Clare Palmer-Fairbairn was ldquoridiculously excited by the message from the Peppa Pig patriarch.Mark McKenzie, who contacted Mr Ridings about the message, said he wanted todo something special for the school.Mark, who lives in Prestonpans with we Laura and their two children, Murray, , and Sophie, seven, is a presenter on BFBS the Forces Station every afternoon and said interviewing lsquoDaddy Pigrsquo Richard last year was a dream for his family.Mark, who has interviewed celebrities from the Bee Gees to David Bowie, said son Murray, who attends The Hub and has a rare chromosome disorder, loved Peppa Pig.He said: ldquoSeeing how Murray responds to the show and his reactions, Peppa Pig has been a regular fixture in our house. When I had the opportunity to interview Richard for BFBS I was excited and nervous ndash he couldnrsquot have been nicer.ldquoWe kept in touch occasionally afterwards he had offered to record a message for my children and I askedhe might share one for the school. He responded straight away.Mark described The Hub, which Murray has been attending since he was three, as ldquoan absolute haven.He said: ldquoThe staff are fantastic and it makes such a dference for us. The integration between the school and Hub is brilliant.Clare Palmer-Fairbairn said: ldquoMark got in touch to say he had a bit of a surprise and, knowing his creative ideas and connections through work, I was intrigued!ldquoMark initially sent the audio clip and I could not believe it was the real deal Daddy Pig! Such a thoughtful and kind gesture from the actor Richard Ridings and for Mark to make this happen.ldquoWe created a bit of suspense prior to the clip being shared, letting the Sandersonrsquos Wynd community know we had a summer message from an international celebrity. There was great excitement and guesses amongst staff as to who it might be!ldquoWhen we shared it in our final week of term, the response was wonderful ndash so many likes and cheerful comments from pupils, staff, parents and carers!ldquoI have been chatting with families over the phone and many spoke about what an amazing surprise this was and how happy it made them.ldquoPart of Daddy Pigrsquos happy message is about smiling, kindness and outdoor learningndash all part of the Sandersonrsquos Wynd approach so we couldnrsquot have asked for a better summer message!

title: pharmacy-owner-retiring-four-decades
story: As he is currently shielding due to the Covid- pandemic, he was sad not to be able to say a fond farewell to his many customers.Eskside Pharmacy has been sold to a new owner and will continue to provide pharmaceutical care for local people.Mr Chetty said: ldquoItrsquos been an immense pleasure to have served the people of Musselburgh and surrounding areas for the last  years. The loyalty and support of the community has been humbling and greatly appreciated.ldquoIrsquom also grateful for the strong working relationships Irsquove had with the surgeries and GPs.ldquoIrsquove been very fortunate to have had such fantastic, hard-working and cheerful staff through all the years and I canrsquot thank them enough for all they have done.ldquoThe current circumstances of Covid- have meant that I havenrsquot been able to say farewells to people in person, which is of great regret. My thoughts will always be with you all and I will still be a regular face up and down High Street.ldquoIrsquom in no doubt the new owners will continue high standards of pharmaceutical care.Mr Chetty, , started at Eskside Pharmacy on High Street in , initially as the manager, before buying the business in .Originally from South Africa, he came to Scotland to study in Edinburgh in the s ndash when apartheid wouldnrsquot allow him to study for the profession in South Africa.As manager of the local pharmacy, he enjoyed the community spirit in Musselburgh and jumped at the chance of establishing and developing the pharmacy.The overriding memory he will take with him is the ldquopositive rapport he has developed with the patients and the people of Musselburgh. He said serving the health and wellbeing of the community had been his number one priority and he always felt that was appreciated by his customers and wider community.He recalled one of his most special memories, when his daughter was in hospital with meningitis and he found out that every church in Musselburgh had said a prayer for her recovery.Just a few months ago, when he was piercing the ears of a girl at the shop, her grandmother told him he had pierced her ears too as well as her daughterrsquos ears, making this the third generation of the same family he had served.He joked that he decided that might be his cue to retire.Mr Chetty, who lives in Longniddry, said Musselburgh had always had a ldquothriving High Street, but it had been challenging to maintain a wide range of businesses to serve the community. He hoped High Street would always remain at the heart of the community.Mr Chetty, who has three children and four grandchildren, one of whom was born just two weeks ago, sadly lost his we Moira two years ago. He said he was ldquovery grateful for the support of the community during her illness and when she passed away.In his retirement, he is looking forward to playing golf, tending his garden and travelling, as well as spending time with his grandchildren. He is also hoping to spend time with family in South Africa.

title: letter-week-need-look-coast
story: The coastline and woodland here are of high conservation value and when the council introduced the coastal car parking policy, they deliberately restricted the spaces here to limit disturbance of the important sensitive habitats and wildle.They could have decided to create a larger car parking area to maximise income but, to their credit, they did not do this.In contrast, they allowed much more parking on the opposite side of the estuary, at John Muir Country Park, which is closer to Dunbar and the East Links Family Park.Such zoning is a useful tool both to provide space for people to freely enjoy the outdoors while also protectinghabitats for wildle and for those who prefer a more peaceful environment.Although I support the actions of the council for the reasons given, I do think they should have gone further and imposed some additional restrictions within the John Muir Country Park on the east side of the estuary.In particular, dogs off the lead persistently disturb feeding and nesting birds and I believe that dogs should only be allowed in the area of the country park west of the car park and toilet blockthey are on a lead.At present the only coastal area on the East Lothian coast where there are restrictions on dogs is the Aberlady Bay nature reserve .We owe it to our citizens and visitors, both now and in the future, to preserve what natural heritage we still have along our coasts.Mark HollingNorth Berwick

title: face-coverings-mandatory-scotlands-shops---rules-exempt
story: During her daily briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish Government has been considering the issue of face coverings "for some time now".She confirmed it will become mandatory in Phase .Why the change Face coverings became mandatory in Scotland on all public transport on June .The First Minister said that "as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors.""This is a really important wayfor all of us to help protect each other and to display that sense of solidarity that has served us well," she said.When does it become mandatory Ms Sturgeon said the enforcement will take place on Phase  - July .However sheurged Scots not to wait until next week, asking them to get into the habit now.How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced MsSturgeon also announced that the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.The First Minister also said  patients have now died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from  on Wednesday.A total of , people have tested positive for the virus, up by five from , the previous day.

title: volvo-recall-170-000-cars-seatbelt-fault---full-list
story: Volvo Cars investigations have founda problem relating to the front seat belt fastening, mounted on the outer side of the front seat.The front seat belt fastening cable may over time suffer title: air-bridges-apply-scotland-can-go-holiday-abroad
